p: An application of wet chemistry procedures [ 5] and several instrumental techniques [ 6, 7, 8, 9, 10], such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), gas chromatography combined with mass spectrometry (GC-MS), Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, stable isotope ratio analysis through nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), isotope ratio mass spectrometry (IRMS), are the most employed analytical methods in wine detection technology. Being quite sophisticated, these techniques require a costly equipment, long time of analysis and trained personnel involvement. Such analyses give information on individual wine components but they cannot provide the global assessment of wine flavour or quality, that makes impossible the most wine frauds detection.
